text.front:
SELF-ASSEMBLED QUANTUM DOT-BASED QUANTUM MEMORY
Q. Wang 1,* and Y-S. Zhang 2
1
Department of Photonics Engineering, DTU, DK-2800 Kgs. Lyngby, Denmark
2 Department of Physics, Key Laboratory of Quantum Information, USTC, 230026, Hefei, China
text.p:
We give a proposal on how to use self-assembled single quantum dot devices to process entanglement
storage, and then analyze the possibility of realizing it with current technology. We also evaluate the storage
fidelity with imperfect experimental conditions and demonstrate that a quite high storage fidelity can still be
obtained.

The main idea is to simultaneously excite electrons in two separate quantum dots with entangled-photon pairs,
thereby transferring the entanglement from photons to electrons, and then coherently map the spin state of each
electron onto the corresponding collective spin of the atomic nuclei that the quantum dot consists of. The
collective spin state of the nuclear ensemble is long lived and therefore useful for storage purpose. Finally, the
entanglement can be retrieved on demand with the reversed process. The processes above are depicted
schematically in Fig. 1. We numerically simulate the storage fidelity variation with errors in nuclear
polarizations (1-P) for any two-qubit input state, in
